meta.title: Ischemic Heart Disease - Coronary Blood Flow

questions.text: Myocardial infarction and stroke are more common during?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Early morning Blood pressure tends to be higher in the early morning hours , soon after waking, than at other times of the day. Myocardial infarction and stroke are more common in the early morning hours. Night-time blood pressures are generally 10–20% lower than daytime blood pressures , and an attenuated night-time blood pressure “dip” may be associated with increased cardiovascular disease risk.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: BP doesn’t fluctuate much to trigger an event. Option: B: BP is less during night time. So, less common.

questions.text: All are features seen in cardiac tamponade except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Rapid Y descent Cardiac tamponade is associated with rapid X descent and not rapid y descent. Note: JVP changes are the most sensitive sign in cardiac tamponade.

Highyeild:

● When the tricuspid valve opens, the pressure goes down, atria start emptying and ventricles start filling leads to produce y-descent. In cardiac tamponade, as the cardiac chamber is strangulated, even after the opening of the tricuspid valve, blood cannot rapidly fall due to high pressure in the ventricles so the y-descent is lost. ● Sharp x-descent - Relaxing of atria produces an x-descent, this x-descent becomes sharp and deeper because high blood pressure in the JVP system eventually fills the atrium when it is relaxing.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- In cardiac tamponade, the heart is strangulated and blood will pool behind, this will raise JVP and leads to distension of the neck veins, which is also called Jugular Venous Distention (JVD) Option C- Kussmaul sign is a feature of constrictive pericarditis and not cardiac tamponade but it can be seen in some patients with cardiac tamponade. It suggests the possibility of epicardial constriction. Option D - In cardiac tamponade, cardiac chambers are compressed or strangulated. There is an increased venous return to the right heart during inspiration and the free wall of the right ventricle cannot expand due to tamponade, So there will be too much deflection of the interventricular septum towards the left side, and the left ventricle becomes extremely under filled, it leads towards the low cardiac output and eventually, there’ll be more drop in systolic blood pressure (>10mmHg)….pulsus paradoxus . So, Options A, C, and D are seen in cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: Atherosclerosis is the buildup of fats, cholesterol, and other substances in and on the artery walls. This buildup is called plaque. The plaque can cause arteries to narrow, blocking blood flow. The plaque can also burst, leading to a blood clot. Which of the following is the most powerful independent risk factor for atherosclerosis in CAD?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Age Age is the most powerful independent risk factor for atherosclerosis and gender also plays a role.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B: Pre-menopausal women have lower rates of disease than men, although the gender difference disappears after menopause. Option: C: Atherosclerotic CAD often runs in families and a positive family history is common in patients with early-onset disease Option: D: There is a strong relationship between cigarette smoking and CAD, especially in younger (< 70 years) individuals, and this is probably the most important modifiable risk factor .

questions.text: Treatment for myocardial ischemia involves improving blood flow to the heart muscle. Treatment may include medications, a procedure to open blocked arteries (angioplasty), or bypass surgery. Making heart-healthy lifestyle choices is important in treating and preventing myocardial ischemia. Which of the following nitrate is available as ointment preparation for IHD?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Nitroglycerin Nitroglycerin is available as an ointment, transdermal patch, spray, and sublingual tablet.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A : Oral and oral sustained-release tablets. Option: B : Oral and oral sustained-release tablets.

Extraedge:

PREPARATION OF AGENT DOSE SCHEDULE Nitroglycerine . Ointment Transdermal patch Sublingual tablet Spray 0.5-2 in 0.2-0.8 mg/h 0.3-0.6 mg One or two sprays Two or three times daily Every 24 h; remove at bedtime for 12-14 h As needed, up to three doses 5 min apart As needed, up to three doses 5 min apart Isosorbide dinitrate a Oral Oral sustained release 10-40 mg 80-120 mg Two or three times daily Once or twice daily (eccentric schedules) Isosorbide 5-mononitrate Oral Oral sustained release 20 mg 30-240 mg Twice daily (given 7-8 h apart Once daily

questions.text: Variant angina, also called Prinzmetal angina, isn't due to coronary artery disease. It's caused by a spasm in the heart's arteries that temporarily reduces blood flow. Severe chest pain is the main symptom of variant angina. It most often occurs in cycles, typically at rest and overnight. Which of the following is NOT used for Prinzmetal’s variant angina?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Aspirin Aspirin may increase the severity of ischemic episodes, possibly as a result of the sensitivity of coronary tone to modest changes in the synthesis of prostacyclin. Prinzmetal’s angina is a form of chest pain, pressure, or tightness (angina) caused by spasms in the arteries that supply blood to the heart. It is a form of unstable angina, meaning that it occurs at rest, often without a predictable pattern . This is in contrast to stable angina, in which chest pain occurs in a predictable pattern during exertion or exercise.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A, B: Nitrates and calcium channel blockers are the main therapeutic agents. Option: D: Statin therapy has been shown to reduce the risk of major adverse events .

questions.text: Which of the following often increases MB isoenzyme of creatinine kinase?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of above CK rises within 4–8 h and generally returns to normal by 48–72 h . The MB isoenzyme of CK has the advantage over total CK in that it is not present in significant concentrations in extracardiac tissue and, therefore, is considerably more specific . However, cardiac surgery, myocarditis, and electrical cardioversion often result in elevated serum levels of the MB Isoenzyme. Option: A, C: Often result in elevated serum levels of MB Isoenzyme. Option: B: Typical cause.

questions.text: An ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) is a type of heart attack that is more serious and has a greater risk of serious complications and death. It gets its name from how it mainly affects the heart's lower chambers and changes how electrical current travels through them. What time is taken by raised CK-MB after STEMI to return to a normal level?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

48-72 hours CK-MB rises within 4–8 h and generally returns to normal by 48–72 h.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: CK-MB rises within 4–8 h Option: C: Troponin comes to normal. Option: D: No significant biochemical markers present.

questions.text: Along with cardiac troponin, which of the following is NOT used to meet the criteria for diagnosis of acute MI?

options.label: D
options.text: Imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium

questions.correct_answer: B. New right bundle branch block (RBBB)
questions.explanation:
Solution:

New right bundle branch block (RBBB) LBBB, not RBBB. Detection of a rise and/or fall of cardiac biomarker values (preferably cardiac troponin [cTn]) with at least one value above the 99 th percentile upper reference limit (URL) and with at least one of the following: Symptoms of ischemia New or presumed new significant ST-segment T-wave (ST-T) change or new left bundle branch block (LBBB) Development of pathologic Q waves in the electrocardiogram (ECG) Imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium or new regional wall motion abnormality Identification of an intracoronary thrombus by angiography or autopsy.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect option: - Option: A, C, D: Included in criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a contraindication to the use of Fibrinolytics in myocardial infarction?

options.label: A
options.text: History of intracranial hemorrhage 6 months back

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Active menstrual bleeding Menstrual bleeding is NOT a contraindication.

Highyeild:

Clear contraindications to the use of fibrinolytic agents include A history of cerebrovascular hemorrhage at any time, a non-hemorrhagic stroke or another cerebrovascular event within the past year, Marked hypertension (a reliably determined systolic arterial pressure >180 mmHg and/or a diastolic pressure >110 mmHg) at any time during the acute presentation, suspicion of aortic dissection, and active Internal bleeding (excluding menses).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: A: CI: A history of cerebrovascular hemorrhage at any time. Option: C: CI: >180 mmHg and/or a diastolic pressure >110 mmHg. Option: D: CI.

questions.text: The amino acid which is associated with atherosclerosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Homocysteine Option A , C and D are not the correct options.

Highyeild:

Precipitating factors:- Fibrinogen Levels 'Fibrinogen levels correlate with coronary risk and provide information regarding coronary risk independent of lipoprotein profile. Elevated fibrinogen levels promots a thrombosis. Waist Hip Ratio: This refers to a characteristic 'male' distribution of adipose tissue l.e. excess of fat in the abdomen compared with that in hips. 'An elevated waist/hip ratio has been associated with symptomatic cardiovascular disease and cerebrovascular disease in both men and women. Hyper homocystinemia There is a strong positive correlation between atherosclerosis and circulating levels of Homocysteine Major factor leading to hyperhomocysteinemia is folate deficiency Condition Risk of CAD Xanthoma Pancreatitis Type I (Familial Hyper Chylomicronemia) Not increased Eruptive +++ Type II A (Familial Hyper Cholesterolemia) Accelerated Tendon 0 Type ll B (Familial Combined Hyperlipidemia Accelerated None 0 Type III (Familial Dysbetalipoproteinemia Accelerated Palmer 0 Type IV (Familial Hypertriglyceridemia) Accelerated None 0 Type V (Familial Mixed Hypertriglyceridemia) Not increased Eruptive +++

questions.text: A 50-year-old male underwent a CT abdomen scan for evaluation of a pulsatile abdominal mass. An image from the CT abdomen is shown below. What is the MC cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Atherosclerosis The CT scan shows a very large Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA ), which is extending from the vertebra to the abdominal wall and creating a bulge on the abdominal wall (arrows). The aortic wall is partly calcified. So, Options B, C, and D are not the correct options.

questions.text: A 45 year old presented to the emergency with a history of chest pain, diaphoresis, and nausea. ECG done showed ST elevation leads v1-v6 with corresponding reciprocal changes. Trop I was elevated. All the following drugs are used in the management of this condition except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Warfarin Management of acute coronary syndrome (ACS) Aspirin 325mg chewed as the loading dose along with clopidogrel 600mg and Atorvastatin 80mg as the loading dose is given before taking up the patient for PCI. GTN sublingual. Analgesia Morphine 2-3 mg IV or 10 – 15 mg IM Thrombolysis , if no contraindication or non-PCI center and timely referral is not feasible, thrombolysis is not done in unstable angina. So, Options B, C, and D are not the correct options as they are used in the management of Acute coronary syndrome.
